overview.title: Scaling a manual CAD process to a nationwide launch
overview.description: The team needed to digitize 1,000 unique AT&T stores to support a major product launch. The previous approach relied on a single designer redrawing every element in SolidWorks, creating a massive bottleneck.

challenge.title: The bottleneck: eight hours per store, per designer
challenge.description: With a 1,000-store backlog, the existing process simply could not scale. Designers redrew walls, fixtures, and signage from scratch for each location while leadership waited for status updates.
list: Manual tracing created high error rates and rework cycles.
No shared library of reusable store components.
Leadership lacked visibility into progress or ROI.

solution.title: A two-step breakthrough
solution.description: We combined a component-based SolidWorks library with automation scripts that generate manufacturing drawings. Designers shifted from drawing from scratch to assembling pre-validated templates.

steps.title: Component library
steps.description: Codified reusable walls, fixtures, and signage elements to reduce repetitive work.

steps.title: Automation scripts
steps.description: Parameterized store templates and outputs so drawings update automatically when inputs change.

steps.title: Feedback instrumentation
steps.description: Instrumentation captured throughput and error rates, enabling continuous optimization.

impact.title: Impact: massive savings and clarity
impact.description: The redesigned flow freed designers to focus on edge cases while leadership gained a dashboard-ready story for investment.
highlights: Automation unlocked same-day turnaround for standard stores.
Leadership approved continued investment in the design system roadmap.
Quality audits reported a 0% defect rate after automation roll-out.

process.title: How we delivered change
process.description: Each sprint paired research with tangible artifacts leadership could sign off on.

sections.title: 1. Understand the friction
sections.description: Qualitative interviews with draftsmen, senior designers, and project managers surfaced the human cost of the old flow.

findings.title: Repetitive manual labor
findings.description: Drawing standard components from scratch drained focus and introduced errors.

findings.title: Lack of standardization
findings.description: Without a component library, drawings were inconsistent across designers.

findings.title: Underused tooling
findings.description: Teams owned SolidWorks automation features but never had time to explore them.

sections.title: 2. Visualize the current state
sections.description: Mapping the as-is workflow created a shared understanding of where hours vanished.

sections.title: 3. Design the future system

conclusion.description: IDL proved that pairing automation with human-centered habits unlocks exponential returns. The same playbook now guides adjacent operations teams.
